sections.title: Handling Financial Disagreements
sections.subtitle: Turn money conflicts into opportunities for growth

sections.title: Why Money Fights Happen
sections.content:
Money is the #1 source of conflict in relationships, and it's not because couples are bad at math. Financial disagreements are rarely about the numbers—they're about values, fears, control, and different life experiences. When you argue about whether to buy a new car, you're really arguing about security vs. freedom, status vs. practicality, or present enjoyment vs. future planning.

Understanding this is the first step to resolving money conflicts. The goal isn't to 'win' the argument—it's to understand each other's underlying needs and find solutions that honor both perspectives.

points.title: Different Money Scripts
points.description: Your childhood experiences shape your money beliefs. A partner who grew up in scarcity may hoard money for security, while one who grew up comfortable may spend freely. Neither is wrong—they're different survival strategies.

points.title: Income Disparities
points.description: When one partner earns significantly more, power dynamics can emerge. The higher earner may feel entitled to more say, while the lower earner may feel guilty or resentful.

points.title: Secret Spending
points.description: Hidden purchases, accounts, or debts destroy trust. Financial infidelity can be as damaging as other forms of betrayal.

points.title: Different Risk Tolerances
points.description: One partner wants to invest aggressively, the other wants everything in savings accounts. Both are trying to feel secure—just in different ways.

points.title: Lifestyle Expectations
points.description: Disagreements about what's 'necessary' vs. 'luxury'—private school, vacations, cars, dining out. These reflect different values and priorities.

sections.title: The CALM Method for Money Conflicts
sections.content:
When a money disagreement arises, use the CALM method:

C - Cool Down First: Never discuss money when emotions are high. If you're angry, take a 20-minute break. Say 'I want to discuss this, but I need some time to think first.' Return when you can speak calmly.

A - Ask Questions: Before defending your position, understand theirs. 'Help me understand why this is important to you.' 'What are you worried might happen?' Listen to understand, not to respond.

L - Look for the Underlying Need: Behind every money position is a need—security, freedom, respect, fairness, or control. Identify the need, and you can often find alternative solutions that meet it.

M - Make a Plan Together: Once you understand each other, brainstorm solutions together. 'What if we...' 'Would it help if...' The goal is a solution you both can live with, even if it's not either person's first choice.

sections.title: The 24-Hour Rule
sections.content: For any financial decision over $200 (or whatever threshold you set), wait 24 hours before deciding. This prevents impulse purchases and gives both partners time to consider the decision without pressure.

sections.title: Scripts for Difficult Conversations
sections.content:
When Your Partner Overspends:
Don't say: 'You're so irresponsible with money!'
Do say: 'I noticed we went over budget this month. Can we look at what happened together and figure out how to adjust?'

When You Disagree on a Purchase:
Don't say: 'That's a waste of money.'
Do say: 'I'm not sure I understand why this is important. Can you help me see it from your perspective?'

When Discussing Debt:
Don't say: 'Your debt is ruining us.'
Do say: 'I want us to tackle this debt together. What's a realistic plan we can both commit to?'

When Income Is Unequal:
Don't say: 'I earn more, so I should decide.'
Do say: 'We're a team regardless of who earns what. How can we make financial decisions that feel fair to both of us?'

When Discovering Hidden Spending:
Don't say: 'How could you lie to me?'
Do say: 'I'm hurt that this was hidden from me. I need to understand what happened so we can rebuild trust.'

sections.title: Resolving a Current Money Conflict
steps: Identify the specific issue - What exactly are you disagreeing about? Be precise.
Schedule a calm conversation - Not during dinner, not before bed, not when stressed.
Each partner shares their perspective without interruption (3-5 minutes each).
Identify the underlying needs - What does each person really want or fear?
Brainstorm at least 3 possible solutions together.
Evaluate each solution - Does it address both partners' needs?
Choose a solution to try for 30-60 days.
Schedule a follow-up to assess if it's working.

sections.title: When to Seek Professional Help
sections.content:
Some money conflicts need outside help. Consider a financial therapist or couples counselor if:

- The same arguments repeat without resolution
- One partner controls all money decisions
- There's been financial infidelity (hidden accounts, secret debt)
- Money discussions always escalate to yelling or stonewalling
- One partner refuses to discuss finances at all
- Financial stress is affecting your mental health or relationship

Financial therapy combines financial planning with psychological support. It's not a sign of failure—it's a sign you're committed to solving the problem.

sections.title: Key Takeaway
sections.content: Money fights are normal—every couple has them. What matters is how you handle them. Approach disagreements with curiosity instead of judgment, focus on understanding rather than winning, and remember you're on the same team working toward shared goals.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: Think about a recent money disagreement. Using the CALM method, identify what the underlying needs were for both of you. Could a different approach have led to a better outcome? Practice these techniques on small disagreements to build the skill before tackling bigger issues.
